string_table.name: pxabnsnfns10111110111
string_table.string: Use the w, a, s, and d keys to move around the 360 degree image. Press the tab key to jump to interactive markers and hotspots.
To watch this video, use the preview feature in Storyline 360, upload your published output to a server, publish to Review 360, or switch to static video quality.
Streaming video is unavailable for local playback.

slidelink.displaytext: QUESTION 1 Directions: Choose either True or False to answer the question below. Then click the “Submit” button to advance to the next question. Question: To create engaging content, you should consider using teaching practices that foster engagement; affinity groups; challenge-based problems; simulations; and case discussions.

QUESTION 2 Directions: Select all answers that apply to the question below. Then click the “Submit” button to advance to the next question. Question: To encourage engagement, do the following (select all that apply):

QUESTION 3 Directions: Fill in the blank with the answer to the question below. Then click the “Submit” button to advance to the next question. Question: Student groups brought together by common interests are called __________ groups.

QUESTION 4 Directions: Select the correct answer to the question below. Then click the “Submit” button to advance to the next question. Question: Activities that approximate “real” situations in which students must make decisions that determine the direction of the events that follow are called:

QUESTION 5 Directions: Choose either True or False to answer the question below. Then click the “Submit” button to advance to the Results slide. Question: In case discussions, students convene only in their small groups to find a solution to a problem. They do not try to come up with individual solutions first.

search.slidetext: creating engaging content michelle metzner
getting started to navigate the course, click the <prev and next> arrows in the lower-right corner of the player (red arrows). to play or pause the timeline, click the button (green arrow).
introduction
instructor information please watch the video below for a brief introduction of your instructor and welcome to the course.
character introduction meet the principal characters in today’s lesson: dr. mary lounsbury and dr. casey atherton.
communication expectations you can either email your questions to me at michelle.metzner@wright.edu, or you can post them to the discussion board in your lms.
course policies please complete all of the activities in the lesson, and pass the final test with an 80% or higher to pass the course.
technology requirements participants must be running at least windows 10 and must sign up for a 30-day trial of articulate storyline.
computer skills required to successfully complete this lesson, you should already know how to use your d2l brightspace lms, including how to send email and post to discussion boards.
prerequisite knowledge expectations this course is designed for experienced higher education instructors of any discipline. learners should come to the lesson with a good grasp of course design.

welcome, %studentname%! i always enjoy working with folks from diverse backgrounds! let’s get started! welcome, %studentname%! i always enjoy working with folks from k-12! let’s get started! welcome, %studentname%! i always enjoy working with folks from sinclair! go, tartans! welcome, %studentname%! i always enjoy working with folks from wright state! go, raiders! learner introduction enter your name in the space provided. below your name, select the institution with which you’re affiliated. then click the submit button. my name is: ____________________________________________________ type your first name here sinclair community college wright state university local high school none of the above

it’s great that you’re feeling fantastic, %studentname%! i know you’re going to love this lesson! click the next button to move to the next section. i’m glad to hear that you’re feeling pretty good right now, %studentname%! it’s going to be smooth sailing for you from here on! click the next button to move to the next section. i’m glad you’re doing fine right now, %studentname%! i have a feeling you’re going to get through this with no problem! click the next button to move to the next section. i’m sorry to hear that you’re a little freaked out, %studentname%! take a deep breath, and we’ll get through this together! click the next button to move to the next section. i’m sorry to hear that you’re totally freaked out, %studentname%! take a deep breath, and we’ll get through this together! click the next button to move to the next section. check-in time! question: on a scale of “totally freaked out” to “no problem – i’ve got this,” how are you feeling about completing this lesson right now? directions: use the slider to answer the question below. images will appear as you move the slider.
trigger phase
the big idea university student enrollment and retention depend on student engagement in their courses (york, 2023).

wow, %studentname% – you have a strong opinion about this topic! it’s okay, %studentname% – sometimes i need more information before i make a decision, too! wow, %studentname% – you strongly agree that student engagement increases university enrollment and retention! survey time! use your mouse to move the dial in answer to the following question: how much do you agree that student engagement increases university enrollment and retention?
the big idea engagement with course content is one of the best predictors of student success in online courses (engage your students in your online course, 2020.)

interesting rankings! i wonder if your answers will change after you complete the lesson . . . full online lectures (30+ minutes) synchronous group discussions true/false quizzes click and drag the boxes to rank these online activities in order of your preferences from most to least engaging. then click submit. interactive lessons (e.g., simulations, case studies, interaction with the instructor) survey time!
the big idea engaging content contributes to more positive outcomes for students, including an increased likelihood of attaining their academic goals (barkley, 2010).

i’m so sorry that the course wasn’t as engaging as it could have been. on the upside, you can use that experience to guide you away from methodologies that didn’t work when it’s time to create your next class. click the next button to move to the next section. that sounds amazing! you might consider incorporating experiences like that into your next online offering. after all, if you thought it was your best online learning experience, then imagine how your students could benefit from it! click the next button to move to the next section. assessment: choose many directions: think of your most memorable online learning experiences, and check the boxes below to indicate which trademarks of effective engagement were present. then click submit. directions: think of your most memorable online learning experiences, and check the boxes below to indicate which trademarks of effective engagement were present. then click submit. directions: think of your most memorable online learning experiences, and check the boxes below to indicate which trademarks of effective engagement were present. then click submit. short, targeted lectures short, targeted lectures short, targeted lectures short, targeted lectures group interactions group interactions group interactions group interactions group interactions group interactions case studies case studies case studies case studies case studies case studies simulations simulations simulations simulations simulations simulations regular and substantive feedback regular and substantive feedback regular and substantive feedback regular and substantive feedback regular and substantive feedback regular and substantive feedback clear instructions and examples clear instructions and examples clear instructions and examples clear instructions and examples clear instructions and examples clear instructions and examples effective use of online meeting technologies effective use of online meeting technologies effective use of online meeting technologies effective use of online meeting technologies effective use of online meeting technologies effective use of online meeting technologies synchronous meetings synchronous meetings synchronous meetings synchronous meetings synchronous meetings synchronous meetings skills-based lessons skills-based lessons skills-based lessons skills-based lessons skills-based lessons skills-based lessons interactive online lessons interactive online lessons interactive online lessons interactive online lessons interactive online lessons interactive online lessons

learning objectives the learning objectives for this lesson are listed below. after this lesson, you’ll be able to: explain the importance of having engaging content in online classes demonstrate three teaching practices that encourage engagement incorporate into your classes at least one of four effective exercise designs that foster student engagement
exploration phase

five best practices for creating engaging content to create engaging content, consider: teaching practices that foster engagement; affinity groups; challenge-based problems; simulations; and case discussions

practice #1: use practices that encourage engagement to encourage engagement: humanize your course; communicate clearly & consistently; remove barriers to engagement; & foster community (nc state, 2023)
practice #2: use affinity groups affinity groups are student groups brought together by common interests, like hobbies, goals, or something unique about them (empire state university 2023).

you matched %numbercorrect%. you might want to revisit the material before trying again. you matched %numbercorrect%. you have no more attempts at this activity. you matched %numbercorrect%. you might want to revisit the material before trying again. try again try again try again try again try again good work remembering that fostering community, removing barriers to engagement, humanizing the course, and communicating consistently all encourage student engagement! great job! you matched %numbercorrect%! assessment: matching directions: drag the examples from the left column to match them with the appropriate practices to encourage engagement in the right column. then click submit. humanize the course be warm, and share something about yourself with your students. be warm, and share something about yourself with your students. be warm, and share something about yourself with your students. be warm, and share something about yourself with your students. be warm, and share something about yourself with your students. use your syllabus to clearly communicate expectations and assignments. use a consistent layout. use your syllabus to clearly communicate expectations and assignments. use a consistent layout. use your syllabus to clearly communicate expectations and assignments. use a consistent layout. use your syllabus to clearly communicate expectations and assignments. use a consistent layout. use your syllabus to clearly communicate expectations and assignments. use a consistent layout. use real examples; offer students choices of learning materials; explain why you chose the content or activities use real examples; offer students choices of learning materials; explain why you chose the content or activities use real examples; offer students choices of learning materials; explain why you chose the content or activities use real examples; offer students choices of learning materials; explain why you chose the content or activities use real examples; offer students choices of learning materials; explain why you chose the content or activities allow for students’ emotional engagement with the material as they form a sense of camaraderie around it. allow for students’ emotional engagement with the material as they form a sense of camaraderie around it. allow for students’ emotional engagement with the material as they form a sense of camaraderie around it. allow for students’ emotional engagement with the material as they form a sense of camaraderie around it. allow for students’ emotional engagement with the material as they form a sense of camaraderie around it. communicate clearly and consistently remove barriers to engagement foster community
practice 3: challenge-based problems challenge-based problems create significant student buy-in because they tap into students’ personal experiences and interests (teachonline.ca, 2020).
practice #4: simulations simulations approximate “real” situations in which students must make decisions that determine the direction of the events that follow (unsw sydney, 2023).

try again try again try again try again try again so close! you selected %numbercorrect% correctly, but you also chose one or two incorrect answers. review the materials before giving it another try! try again try again try again try again try again so close! you selected %numbercorrect% correctly. review the material, and then give it another try! you have no more attempts at this activity. review the material, and then give it another try! you were savvy enough to remember that dinner choices and favorite childhood memories do not make for good group challenges! great job! you selected %numbercorrect%! mental health mental health mental health mental health mental health mental health climate change climate change climate change climate change climate change climate change what to have for dinner what to have for dinner what to have for dinner what to have for dinner what to have for dinner what to have for dinner loneliness loneliness loneliness loneliness loneliness loneliness community development community development community development community development community development community development favorite childhood memory favorite childhood memory favorite childhood memory favorite childhood memory favorite childhood memory favorite childhood memory assessment: choose more than one directions: please choose the correct answers to the question below. then click submit. question: which of the following topics would be good to use in a challenge-based problem?
practice #5: case discussions all students receive a problem. students decide how they will solve the problem on their own before forming small discussion groups (teachonline.ca).

almost! you chose %numbercorrect% correctly, but you also chose one or two incorrect answers. review the material, and then give it another go! try again try again try again try again try again almost! you chose %numbercorrect% correctly. review the material, and then give it another go! you have no more attempts at this activity. review the material, and then give it another go! try again try again try again try again try again fantastic job! you correctly chose %numbercorrect%! nice work remembering that getting more time to relax and having the opportunity to foist work off on others don’t help students in case discussions! increased collaboration increased collaboration increased collaboration increased collaboration increased collaboration increased collaboration sharpened problem-solving skills sharpened problem-solving skills sharpened problem-solving skills sharpened problem-solving skills sharpened problem-solving skills sharpened problem-solving skills time to relax time to relax time to relax time to relax time to relax time to relax more practice with their presentation skills more practice with their presentation skills more practice with their presentation skills more practice with their presentation skills more practice with their presentation skills more practice with their presentation skills more chances to have others do the heavy lifting more chances to have others do the heavy lifting more chances to have others do the heavy lifting more chances to have others do the heavy lifting more chances to have others do the heavy lifting more chances to have others do the heavy lifting assessment: choose more than one question: judging by what you learned about the case discussions, which of the following are student benefits of using case discussions? select all that apply; then click submit. directions: please choose the correct answers to the question below. then click submit.
great work! you did a fantastic job of learning about the 5 best practices for creating engaging content! next, you’ll test your skills in a scenario activity!
integration phase
scenario character introduction %studentname%, meet dr. mary lounsbury and dr. casey atherton of the phinneas college english department.
scenario as chair, mary has conducted her 5-year review of the department’s courses, and she’s discovered that casey’s online business writing course could use some updating.
scenario work through the lesson, %studentname%, and help casey select new content that will engage his online business writing students.

expectations the following outlines the expectations for the scenario activity: the scenario includes three activities. two activities will require you to drag and drop your answers, and one will require you to click to reveal items. please repeat the activities up to three times to earn 100% on each. this exercise should take you no longer than 30 minutes to complete, but take as much or as little time as necessary.

the problem hey, casey! if you have a minute, i’d like to talk with you about updating your online business writing course. sure thing, mary. what’s up? i’ve noticed that your class doesn’t offer a lot of opportunities for student engagement. oh, no – really? i thought i was doing well with that. but if you think engagement is lacking, i’ll take another look. sounds good! let me know when you want me to take another look, casey! good luck! i guess i’ll need to look at my teaching practices, but i can’t remember which four will encourage engagement most effectively . . .

try again try again try again try again try again so close! you filed %numbercorrect% correctly. so close! you filed %numbercorrect% correctly. take another look at the lecture content before you give try it again! you have no more attempts at this activity. click the next button to continue. take another look at the lecture content before you give try it again! yes, humanizing the course, removing barriers to engagement, communicating clearly, and fostering community all lead to increased engagement! outstanding! you correctly filed %numbercorrect%/4! matching activity 1: teaching practices if you were casey, which of the following teaching practices would you put in your briefcase? which would you toss in the trash can? drag your choices to their appropriate locations now! humanize the course record & post full-length lectures create unmonitored discussion exercises remove barriers to engagement with content foster community create true/false quizzes communicate clearly & consistently hold office hours via email

the problem (part 2) hey, casey! i just saw your revisions – nice work on updating your teaching practices! thanks, mary! i’m glad you like the updates! updating my practices didn’t take long at all! i’m all set! slow your roll there, casey – i didn’t say you were done. there are four more practices that involve activity design that you need to look at. oh, you thought i was done? nope – not me! always working on getting those students engaged . . . glad to hear it! i’ll check in on you later to see how the redesign is going. oh, man . . . what am i going to do? i don’t remember any of the remaining four activity design practices . . .
click-to-reveal activity 1: activity design click on the file folders to find the four activity design practices that casey can’t seem to remember.

i’m sorry – you matched %numbercorrect% i’m sorry – you matched %numbercorrect% i’m sorry – you matched %numbercorrect% you might go back and look at the material again before giving it another try! you matched %numbercorrect%. you have no more attempts at this activity. click the next button to continue. you might go back and look at the material again before giving it another try! try again try again try again try again try again great job! you matched %numbercorrect%/4! once you understand how to use affinity groups, case discussions, challenge-based problems, and simulations, you’re well on your way to creating engaging courses for your students! matching activity 2: activity design drag the activity examples from the left column, and drop them on the name of their correct design types in the right column. create significant student buy-in because the topics involve students’ personal interests, mental health, gender and racial equality, climate change, and loneliness. create significant student buy-in because the topics involve students’ personal interests, mental health, gender and racial equality, climate change, and loneliness. students devise a solution on their own and then they present their solutions one-by-one to the small group, and the group decides how best to proceed. students form teams based on common interests, like hobbies, life goals, or something interesting about them approximate “real” situations in which students must make decisions that determine the direction of the events that follow affinity groups affinity groups affinity groups challenge-based problems challenge-based problems challenge-based problems simulations simulations simulations case discussions case discussions case discussions

the problem (part 2) hey, casey! i just saw your final revisions – fantastic job on making your online course more engaging for your students! oh, that’s great, mary! i’m so glad you approve of them! approve of them?! i love them! i think i’m going to run it by writing programs to see if they’ll be open to running your course as the master for the department! great work! that’s so exciting – thank you! um, if you use my course as the department master, does that mean i’ll get a pay bump? nice try . . .
great work! fantastic job working through the scenario, %studentname%! now you know all about the tools you can use to create engaging content!
resolution phase
quiz directions this quiz consists of 5 questions and should take you no longer than 15 minutes to complete by clicking the correct answers or filling in the blanks.
quiz directions you must earn at least 80% to pass the quiz. email your instructor if you have technical issues.
quiz directions to begin the quiz, click the “next” button. click “continue” on each question slide to go to the next question.

incorrect you did not select the correct response. try to remember the types of activities that keep you engaged in online classes; those are the types of activities you might want to embed in your own courses. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct great job! case discussions, simulations, challenge-based problem, affinity groups, and teaching practices that foster engagement are important elements of successful online classes! continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false question 1 directions: choose either true or false to answer the question below. then click the “submit” button to advance to the next question. question: to create engaging content, you should consider using teaching practices that foster engagement; affinity groups; challenge-based problems; simulations; and case discussions.

incorrect while full lectures provide a lot of information, they are often boring or overwhelming to students, so keep it short! continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! and while full lectures can provide a lot of information, they are often boring or overwhelming for students, so keep it short! continue continue continue continue continue continue humanize your course humanize your course humanize your course humanize your course humanize your course humanize your course communicate clearly and consistently communicate clearly and consistently communicate clearly and consistently communicate clearly and consistently communicate clearly and consistently communicate clearly and consistently post full lectures post full lectures post full lectures post full lectures post full lectures post full lectures remove barriers to engagement remove barriers to engagement remove barriers to engagement remove barriers to engagement remove barriers to engagement remove barriers to engagement foster community foster community foster community foster community foster community foster community question 2 directions: select all answers that apply to the question below. then click the “submit” button to advance to the next question. question: to encourage engagement, do the following (select all that apply):

incorrect not this time. try to remember the answer this way: people who get along well and form a group are usually said to have an affinity for one another. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! affinity groups bring students together and encourage bonding over common interests, like hobbies, interests, professional direction, etc. continue continue continue continue continue continue question 3 directions: fill in the blank with the answer to the question below. then click the “submit” button to advance to the next question. question: student groups brought together by common interests are called __________ groups.

incorrect good try! you might want to take another look at the material before giving it another go. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! simulations put students in “real” situations, so they have the opportunity to decide what they would do and how their actions affect the outcome of the event. continue continue continue continue continue continue case discussions case discussions case discussions case discussions case discussions case discussions challenge-based problems challenge-based problems challenge-based problems challenge-based problems challenge-based problems challenge-based problems affinity groups affinity groups affinity groups affinity groups affinity groups affinity groups simulations simulations simulations simulations simulations simulations question 4 directions: select the correct answer to the question below. then click the “submit” button to advance to the next question. question: activities that approximate “real” situations in which students must make decisions that determine the direction of the events that follow are called:

incorrect you did not select the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue correct that's right! you selected the correct response. continue continue continue continue continue continue true true true true true true false false false false false false question 5 directions: choose either true or false to answer the question below. then click the “submit” button to advance to the results slide. question: in case discussions, students convene only in their small groups to find a solution to a problem. they do not try to come up with individual solutions first.
thank you! thank you for joining me for this lesson in which we learned about how to create engaging online content.
conclusion i hope you can use the 5 tips for creating engaging online content to develop courses your students will enjoy and learn from your years to come!

references barkley, e.f. (2010). student engagement techniques (1st ed., higher and adult education series). san francisco, calif: jossey-bass. empire state university (2023). engaging students in a virtual environment. empire state university: faculty resources for online learning. https://www.sunyempire.edu/dlis/teach-your-course/engaging-students-in- a-digital-environment/ engage your students in your online course: 20 proven ways! (2020, august 18). teachonline.ca. https://teachonline.ca/tools-trends/engage-your-students- your-online-course-20-proven-ways nc state university. (2023). engagement in synchronous and asynchronous environments. nc state university: teaching resources. https://teaching- resources.delta.ncsu.edu/engagement/

references unsw sydney. (2023, april 10). simulations. unsw sydney: teaching. https://www.teaching.unsw.edu.au/simulations york, d. (2023, may 5). how to design online classes for higher engagement and retention. edtech: focus on higher education. https://edtechmagazine.com/ higher/article/2023/05/how-design-online-classes-higher-engagement-and- retention

resource_data.description: Here are some useful links and documents:

resource.title: Engage Your Students in Your Online Course: 20 Proven Ways!
Engaging Students in a Virtual Environment
Engagement in Synchronous and Asynchronous Environments
edtechmHow to Design Online Classes for Higher Engagement and Retentionagazine.com

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
<Document xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema"> <Content> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Survey Time!
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Click and drag the boxes to rank these online activities in order of your preferences from most to least engaging. Then click Submit.
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="Your choices are:
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="1. Interactive lessons (for example, simulations, case studies, interaction with the instructor)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="2. Full online lectures (of 30 or more minutes)
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="3. Synchronous group discussions
" /> </Block> <Block> <Style Justification="Left" /> <Span Text="4. True/False quizzes" /> </Block> </Content> </Document>

terms.term: Student groups brought together by common interests, like hobbies, life goals, or something interesting about them (Empire State University, 2023).
Class activities in which all students receive a problem. Students decide how they will solve the problem on their own before forming small discussion groups (TeachOnline.ca).
Class activities that create significant student buy-in because they tap into students’ personal experiences and interests (TeachOnline.ca, 2020).

An approach to course design and classroom management that will encourage engagement. Be warm, and share something about yourself with your students, which will help students engage emotionally (NC State, 2023).
Class activities that approximate “real” situations in which students must make decisions that determine the direction of the events that follow (UNSW Sydney, 2023).
